bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Elizabeth Peabody, October 21, 1940

div1.p: Hench assures Peabody that her students would be welcome at the Lazear memorial event. He will send the Peabodys a copy of his speech and would like a list of slides from her.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Elizabeth Peabody, October 21, 1940
div1.p:
My correspondence in the matter of the yellow
fever experiments has been so voluminous in the last month,
as I have been rushing to finish my paper, that I find I have
inadvertently failed to answer two or three letters, yours
among them. I apologize sincerely for this oversight.

I am sure that the dedication exercises for the
Lazear Memorial are open to the public, and I would suggest
that your students have no hesitancy in attending. It would
be better, however, if you would write to Miss Neva Hough,
secretary to the President of Washington and Jefferson, and
let her know how many might be there. Even at this late date
I believe they could get you reserved seats. There will be
a play, “Yellow Jack” given Friday night, the dedication cere-
money will be Saturday morning at ten o'clock and my address
will be given at the Founders' Day dinner Saturday night.
Lazear took the first two or three years of his college course
at Washington and Jefferson.

You and your father will be interested to know of some
of the discoveries we have made, and I will send you both the
manuscript of my talk as soon as I can. Meanwhile, if you will
send me a list of the slides that you have, I shall be glad,
indeed to have them. It is possible that I may already have
most of the material.
